content.description:
If you decide to start pitch one directly beneath the roof (this will be obvious)--this will be the crux.  Our original line began here and almost ended here after the leader took a 25 foot fall and ripped a few pieces of gear.  The rock is mediocre as well as the gear so prepare accordingly. 

  A safer and more sane alternative is to climb the nice looking crack up to the jojoba bush and either belay here (one bolt) or continue the traverse to the two bolted belay further right.  The traverse is tricky and the boulder problem finish to the belay keeps your attention.  From the two bolt belay head straight up the crack system and eventually angling left (a short section of face)  to another nice bolted belay stance.  This pitch is just under 100 feet. 

  The final pitch is the same as Pokey Dance. 

  The route was climbed from the ground-up over the course of a few weekends after it was spied from climbing the other routes on this formation.  We had many debates on the approach regarding route safety, ethics of putting up a route and finally does any of this stuff even matter....
content.protection: We used nuts and cams from the tiniest to a #5.  All the belays are bolted and comfortable and there are three bolts on the route.  Out of the three, one can be used as belay for pitch one, one you will be very happy to clip and one is nearing 40 years old.
content.location: The route is several hundred feet north of Rockabilly and Pockey Dance.  At the base of the route there is nice "sundeck boulder" to stash gear and rope-up.  You will be able to see the bolt that protects the traverse from the boulder.   You can rappel the route with three single rope rappels back to the sundeck boulder.

content.description:
A neat route with some fine rock and poor protection.  The first crux can be found on pitch one near the top.  Climb cracks through mini roof to a somewhat distinct "point".  You exit left at this point up a steep, 12 foot face with good pockets.  If you were to continue off the "point" the crack deteriorates.  Belay at nice ledge.   Pitch 2 begins by climbing up an unprotected 12 foot face to another nice ledge.  Either have your belayer spot you or do not fall--would not be good!  Traverse right and up using small, shallow cracks for gear (a fall here might be bad as well).  You will notice a lone bolt off right and below as you traverse.  Bolt is for another route.  Continue up/over bulge to summit. 

*The rating feels fair but the boulder problem after P1 and marginal gear on P2 might get some folks into a bit of trouble**
content.location: Bushwhack from trail just past Twilight Pinnacle (20 minutes from trail to base) or continue on main trail (Dutchman's Trail) to saddle and wander back along the entire formation to the start.  The start is just above a lone juniper tree, the cracks will be obvious.   From the summit walk back to your packs, about 20-30 minutes.

climbs.name: Pseudonym
climbs.fa: B. Sewery, Frank Hill, Fred Hill

content.description: One of the better 5.9 routes I have climbed in the Superstitions.  The rock is good and the protection is always available.  The first pitch is around 90 feet if you belay in the obvious alcove (also the start of the second pitch of The Anonymous) and the second pitch is a little bit longer.  The third pitch has many options and takes you to the summit.
content.protection: One or two bolts depending on how you finish the upper pitch.  Cams to #4 and nuts.  Bolted belay on the "window ledge" and bolts to rap off the summit.
content.location: The start is almost directly below the "window" of the formation.  The start is the same for the route The Anonymous.  The route should be very obvious from the base and while on the approach.     You can either rappel of the summit (west side), walk off the "window ledge" belay to the south and back to your packs (20 minutes of walking) or do three single rope rappels back to the base/packs after you locate the rap anchors near the top-out for Rockabilly.

content.description: This route felt easier than its neighbor Rockabilly.  The first 35 feet of the route is the same as Rockabilly but at the mini-roof angle right and follow cracks and pockets to first belay.  There is one old bolt at the belay that can be easily backed up with a cam or nut.  Pitch 2 heads up a decent face to base of slab that can not be seen from the belay.  There are some loose blocks as you pull onto the slab/face as well as an old bolt you can clip.  Either continue up the finishing moves of Rockabilly or angle right and head for the top.
content.protection: Cams to #4, nuts and two old bolts and one old piton (on the first pitch).
content.location: The approach and start of the route is the same as Rockabilly.  You can rappel the Lower East Wall--3 single rope rappels.

content.description: A pretty cool route that might frighten the beginning  5.7 leader.  The second pitch, while never that difficult, felt a tad loose and exposed even though it was a chimney and ledge system.  Climbing this route and Pseudonym and some of the shorter summit routes makes for a good day of scrambling.
content.protection: One bolt on the first pitch, bolted belay on the "window ledge", rap bolts on the summit.  Cams to #4 and nuts.
content.location: The route begins beneath the "window", climbs the first pitch of Pseudonym and then climbs a long chimney system that remains hidden until the start of the second pitch.     One single rope off the west side of the formation.

content.description: On the east-facing wall, below the three upper needles, and above Miners Canyon.
